prompt: <description>**Instructions for Creating the First Part** **Shape:** A three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Begin by creating a new coordinate system. Set the euler angles to (0, 0, -90) degrees and the translation vector to (0, 0.375, 0). This will position and orient the coordinate system for the first part. Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. The sketch should include the following: - Face 1: - Loop 1: - Line 1: Start Point (0, 0), End Point (0.375, 0) - Line 2: Start Point (0.375, 0), End Point (0.375, 0.375) - Line 3: Start Point (0.375, 0.375), End Point (0, 0.375) - Line 4: Start Point (0, 0.375), End Point (0, 0) The first part is completed by scaling the sketch by a factor of 0.375, transforming it to 3D sketch with the given euler angles and translation vector, and then extruding the sketch with an extrusion depth of 0.1875 in both the normal direction and the opposite direction of the normals. **Instructions for Creating the Second Part** **Shape:** A three-dimensional, rectangular prism with a single, angled cutout on one of its faces. Create a new coordinate system identical to the one used for the first part, with euler angles (0, 0, -90) and translation vector (0, 0.375, 0). Draw a 2D sketch on the X-Y plane of the new coordinate system. The sketch should include: - Face 1: - Loop 1: - Line 1: Start Point (0, 0), End Point (0.375, 0) - Line 2: Start Point (0.375, 0), End Point (0.375, 0.375) - Line 3: Start Point (0.375, 0.375), End Point (0, 0.375) - Line 4: Start Point (0, 0.375), End Point (0, 0) - Face 2: - Loop 1: - Line 1: Start Point (0, 0.375), End Point (0.375, 0.375) - Line 2: Start Point (0.375, 0.375), End Point (0.375, 0.75) - Line 3: Start Point (0.375, 0.75), End Point (0, 0.75) - Line 4: Start Point (0, 0.75), End Point (0, 0.375) - Face 3: - Loop 1: - Line 1: Start Point (0.375, 0), End Point (0.75, 0) - Line 2: Start Point (0.75, 0), End Point (0.75, 0.375) - Line 3: Start Point (0.75, 0.375), End Point (0.375, 0.375) - Line 4: Start Point (0.375, 0.375), End Point (0.375, 0) The second part is created by scaling the sketch by a factor of 0.75, transforming it into 3D Sketch with the same euler angles and translation vector, and then extruding the sketch with an extrusion depth of 0.375 in the normal direction. The operation to be used is JoinFeatureOperation. This completes the instructions for generating a parametric CAD model based on the JSON provided. By following these instructions, a junior CAD designer should be able to create an accurate representation of the described parts.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: A long, thin, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom The first part of the CAD model is a long, thin, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. This part is constructed by creating a new coordinate system, drawing a 2D sketch on a plane defined by the coordinate system, scaling the sketch, transforming the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using euler angles and a translation vector, and then extruding the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model. Step 1: Create a new coordinate system Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: * Euler Angles: [-90.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.75, 0.0, 0.0] Step 2: Draw a 2D sketch Draw a 2D sketch on a plane defined by the coordinate system. The sketch should have the following components: * Face 1 + Loop 1 - Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.0375, 0.0] - Line 2: Start Point [0.0375, 0.0], End Point [0.0375, 0.0125] - Line 3: Start Point [0.0375, 0.0125], End Point [0.0, 0.0125] - Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.0125], End Point [0.0, 0.0] Step 3: Scale the 2D sketch Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.0375. Step 4: Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the following euler angles and translation vector: * Euler Angles: [-90.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.75, 0.0, 0.0] Step 5: Extrude the 2D sketch Extrude the 2D sketch by a depth of 0.75 in the direction opposite of the normal. The resulting 3D model will be a long, thin, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Final shape A long, thin, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. Dimensions * Length: 0.75 * Width: 0.0375 * Height: 0.0375</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1 Instructions Construct a three-dimensional, rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The sides of the prism are parallel and meet at right angles. The dimensions of the prism are 2 units by 3 units by 4 units. 1. Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and a translation vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0375]. 2. Draw the first face of the 2D sketch with the following loops and lines: - Loop 1: Draw a rectangle with the following lines: - Line 1: [0.0, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.0] - Line 2: [0.75, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.675] - Line 3: [0.75, 0.675] to [0.0, 0.675] - Line 4: [0.0, 0.675] to [0.0, 0.0] 3. Scale the 2D sketch by 0.75. 4. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and translation vector [0.0, 0.0, 0.0375]. 5. Extrude the 3D sketch by 0.003 units towards the normal. Part 2 Instructions Construct a rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom, and a curved side. The prism is centered on a white background. 1. Create a new coordinate system with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and a translation vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0375]. 2. Draw the first face of the 2D sketch with the following loops and lines: - Loop 1: Draw a rectangle with the following lines: - Line 1: [0.0, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.0] - Line 2: [0.75, 0.0] to [0.75, 0.675] - Line 3: [0.75, 0.675] to [0.0, 0.675] - Line 4: [0.0, 0.675] to [0.0, 0.0] 3. Scale the 2D sketch by 0.75. 4. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch with euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and translation vector [0.0, 0.0, 0.0375]. 5. Extrude the 3D sketch by 0.0405 units towards the normal. Note: The first part is a simple rectangular prism, but the second part has a curved side. Make sure to draw the correct loops and lines to form the curved side in the 2D sketch, and then extrude it to create the final shape.</description>
